org.apache.juneau.urlencoding

Class UrlEncodingSerializerContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.Context
      • org.apache.juneau.serializer.SerializerContext
        • org.apache.juneau.urlencoding.UonSerializerContext
          • org.apache.juneau.urlencoding.UrlEncodingSerializerContext

  • public class UrlEncodingSerializerContext
extends UonSerializerContext
    Configurable properties on the UrlEncodingSerializer class.

    Context properties are set by calling ContextFactory.setProperty(String, Object) on the context factory returned CoreApi.getContextFactory().

    The following convenience methods are also provided for setting context properties:

    • UrlEncodingSerializer.setProperty(String,Object)
    • UrlEncodingSerializer.setProperties(ObjectMap)
    • UrlEncodingSerializer.addNotBeanClasses(Class[])
    • UrlEncodingSerializer.addBeanFilters(Class[])
    • UrlEncodingSerializer.addPojoSwaps(Class[])
    • UrlEncodingSerializer.addToDictionary(Class[])
    • UrlEncodingSerializer.addImplClass(Class,Class)

    See ContextFactory for more information about context properties.

    Author:
    James Bognar (james.bognar@salesforce.com)

    • Field Detail

      • URLENC_expandedParams

        public static final String URLENC_expandedParams
        Serialize bean property collections/arrays as separate key/value pairs (Boolean, default=false).

        If false, serializing the array [1,2,3] results in ?key=$a(1,2,3). If true, serializing the same array results in ?key=1&key=2&key=3.

        Example:

        public class A { public String[] f1 = {"a","b"}; public List<String> f2 = new LinkedList<String>(Arrays.asList(new String[]{"c","d"})); } UrlEncodingSerializer s1 = new UrlEncodingParser(); UrlEncodingSerializer s2 = new UrlEncodingParser().setProperty(UrlEncodingContext.URLENC_expandedParams, true); String s1 = p1.serialize(new A()); // Produces "f1=(a,b)&f2=(c,d)" String s2 = p2.serialize(new A()); // Produces "f1=a&f1=b&f2=c&f2=d"

        Important note: If parsing multi-part parameters, it's highly recommended to use Collections or Lists as bean property types instead of arrays since arrays have to be recreated from scratch every time a value is added to it.

        This option only applies to beans.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values
